para.paratext: Formerly, no opinion testimony as to the ultimate issue in a case was admissible. Early federal cases construed the ultimate issue rule strictly, but federal courts relaxed its application over time.

Now, Fed. R. Evid. 704 and O.C.G.A. § 24-7-704 provide that testimony in the form of an opinion or inference otherwise admissible is not objectionable because it embraces an ultimate issue to be decided by the trier of fact. However, a witness may not testify as to whether a victim is telling the truth.[1] Moreover, experts may not give an opinion about whether a criminal defendant did or did not have the mental state or condition constituting an element of the crime.
This rule applies to all criminal proceedings, not just those in which competency is at issue.[2] However, this rule applies only to expert witnesses.[3]
These provisions that expressly allow a lay witness to give an opinion as to the ultimate issue in the case are a departure from prior federal common law standards prohibiting such testimony.[4]

Lay opinion testimony as to the ultimate issue in a case is admissible if it does not contain legal conclusions or opinions.[5] Moreover, expert opinion as to the ultimate issue to be decided by the trier of fact is also admissible.[6]

This had been a troubling area of law for Georgia courts. Over time, Georgia courts analyzed the problem more specifically and determined that the real consideration was whether the question the witness was asked to answer was a proper one for opinion evidence.[7] A proper question for opinion evidence was one in which the lay witness was asked to draw an inference of fact from data observed by him or the expert witness was asked to draw an inference of fact from data observed by him or presented by other witnesses.

The Georgia Supreme Court clarified the rule regarding opinion testimony in Metropolitan Life Ins. Co. v. Saul,[8] which held that a physician could state his expert opinion that the plaintiff was totally and permanently disabled, even though this was “the ultimate question to be decided by the jury.” The trial court also permitted lay witnesses to state opinions in the same general area. It was only when drawing the inference required a mixture of law and fact that the question became improper for opinion testimony. For example, in Gage v. Tiffin Motor Homes, Inc.,[9] the court held that a question which included a legal term did not necessarily call for a legal conclusion and that the question was proper for lay opinion testimony.[10] Likewise, the courts have held that officers may give opinion testimony as to the state of sobriety of a DUI suspect.[11] As to expert testimony regarding the suggestibility of a witness, even though an expert witness's testimony that a victim is telling the truth constitutes improper bolstering, it is admissible for a forensic interviewer to testify regarding the suggestibility of a child.[12] A forensic interviewer does not improperly bolster the credibility of a victim when they testify as to the victim's demeanor being consistent with sexual abuse.[13]
Chamberlain v. State, 347 Ga. App. 775, 819 S.E.2d 303 (2018).
Percell v. State, 346 Ga. App. 219, 816 S.E.2d 344 (2018).
See Donlin v. Aramark Corp., 162 F.R.D. 149 (D. Utah 1995); Grier v. State, 305 Ga. 882, 828 S.E.2d 304 (2019).

See Slayton v. Ohio Dept. of Youth Services, 206 F.3d 669, 54 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 126, 2000 FED App. 0091P (6th Cir. 2000); Traumann v. Southland Corp., 858 F. Supp. 979 (N.D. Cal. 1994); U.S. v. Kingston, 971 F.2d 481, 36 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 545 (10th Cir. 1992).

Although an expert may testify as to his opinion on ultimate issues of fact, the expert may not testify as to the law or tell the jury what result to reach. See, e.g., Southern Pine Helicopters, Inc. v. Phoenix Aviation Managers, Inc., 320 F.3d 838, 60 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 817 (8th Cir. 2003); Good Shepherd Manor Foundation, Inc. v. City of Momence, 323 F.3d 557, 60 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1616 (7th Cir. 2003); Montgomery v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 898 F.2d 1537, 30 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 233 (11th Cir. 1990).
In Interest of R. S. T., 345 Ga. App. 300, 812 S.E.2d 614 (2018).

E.g., Grismore v. Consolidated Products Co., 232 Iowa 328, 5 N.W.2d 646 (1942); Bruce v. O'Neal Flying Service, 234 N.C. 79, 66 S.E.2d 312 (1951); Hooper v. General Motors Corp., 123 Utah 515, 260 P.2d 549 (1953). The statements in this paragraph were quoted with approval from the Dual S. Enterprises, Inc. v. Webb, 138 Ga. App. 810, 227 S.E.2d 418 (1976) and Hogan v. City-County Hospital of LaGrange, 138 Ga. App. 906, 227 S.E.2d 796 (1976), followed in Security Life Ins. Co. of Georgia v. Blitch, 155 Ga. App. 167, 270 S.E.2d 349 (1980). See Reed v. Heffernan, 171 Ga. App. 83, 318 S.E.2d 700 (1984) (overruled on other grounds by, Brown v. State, 274 Ga. 31, 549 S.E.2d 107 (2001)); Ford Motor Co. v. Stubblefield, 171 Ga. App. 331, 319 S.E.2d 470 (1984); Nichols v. State, 177 Ga. App. 689, 340 S.E.2d 654 (1986) (citing this work).
Metropolitan Life Ins. Co. v. Saul, 189 Ga. 1, 5 S.E.2d 214 (1939); Holt v. State, 147 Ga. App. 186, 248 S.E.2d 223 (1978); Stewart v. State, 246 Ga. 70, 268 S.E.2d 906 (1980).

There may be some statutory exceptions, however. For example, in cases where the expert is offering an opinion on the market value of property, former O.C.G.A. § 24-9-67.1 (now O.C.G.A. §§ 24-7-702 and 24-7-703) does not apply and Daubert standards need not be used for admission of such opinions. See O.C.G.A. § 24-7-701, which provides:

Direct testimony as to market value is in the nature of opinion evidence. One need not be an expert or dealer in the article in question but may testify as to its value if he has had an opportunity for forming a correct opinion.
Gage v. Tiffin Motor Homes, Inc., 153 Ga. App. 704, 266 S.E.2d 345 (1980).

In Gage v. Tiffin Motor Homes, Inc., 153 Ga. App. 704, 266 S.E.2d 345 (1980), the witness was asked whether he was “under a security agreement with anyone as to your inventory …?” Objection was made that the question called for a “legal conclusion.”
Scott v. State, 332 Ga. App. 559, 774 S.E.2d 137 (2015).
Bowman v. State, 332 Ga. App. 766, 774 S.E.2d 805 (2015).
Chamberlain v. State, 347 Ga. App. 775, 819 S.E.2d 303 (2018).
